title-group.article-title: A critical review on the biological impact of natural organic matter on nanomaterials in the aquatic environment

institution-wrap.institution: The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST)
Center for Safety of Substances and Products, National Institute of Public Health and the Environment (RIVM)
Department of Experimental Limnology, Leibniz Institute for Freshwater Ecology and Inland Fisheries
State Key Laboratory of Environmental Criteria and Risk Assessment, Chinese research academy of environmental sciences
Beijing Advanced Innovation Center for Big Data-Based Precision Medicine

fn.p: Xiangrui Wang and Dingyuan Liang contributed equally to this work.

sec.p: Nanomaterials (NMs) are able to interact with natural organic matter (NOM) such that NOM is adsorbed on the surface of NMs to form an ecological corona (eco-corona). The formation of an eco-corona can greatly influence the behavior, risk and fate of NMs in the environment. A systematic understanding of the impacts of an eco-corona on the hazards of NMs is crucial for NMs risk assessment in the aquatic environment. Herein, the mechanisms of the formation of an eco-corona were reviewed based on the representative literatures and their generality was discussed on the basis of the type of NMs, the type of NOM and the environmental conditions. The effects of an eco-corona on the bioaccumulation and toxicity of NMs for aquatic organisms were systematically discussed through reported studies. The results showed that an eco-corona could alter the toxicity of NMs by changing the dissolution of NMs, adhesion of NMs and the damages to bio-membranes, internalization, and the generation of NMs-induced reactive oxygen species. The dual effects of an eco-corona on the toxicity/accumulation of NMs were widely present because of the complex molecular composition of NOM, the diverse types of NMs, and the variable environmental conditions. The effects of an eco-corona on the fate and the effects of other pollutants (such as metals and organic pollutants) were also carefully reviewed. The results showed that more research is needed to investigate the effect of an eco-corona through the development of novel techniques, mathematical modeling, and mesocosm studies.

abstract.title: Highlights
abstract.p: The dual effects of an eco-corona on NMs’ toxicity/accumulation were widely present.
The effect of an eco-corona was related to the types of NOM and NMs.
Novel techniques is needed to assess the effect of an eco-corona.

institution-wrap.institution: National Natural Science Foundation of China

notes.title: Supplementary Information
notes.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at https://doi.org/10.1007/s44246-022-00013-5.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Nanotechnology has greatly expanded the application of nanomaterials (NMs) in various fields including cosmetics, medical treatments, electronic industry, and mechanical engineering (Grieger et al. 2019; Hochella et al. 2019; Zeng et al. 2021). However, the release of manufactured NMs from these consumer products or their emissions through industrial discharge may induce a risk for ecological systems and human beings. It was estimated that the concentrations of discharged NMs in the surface and effluent waters could reach μg/L levels (Giese et al. 2018; Gottschalk et al. 2009; Keller and Lazareva 2014). Lab-scale experiments have showed that NMs could induce oxidative damage or adsorb enzymes to interrupt the metabolic activity of organisms (Borandeh et al. 2021; Nguyen et al. 2018; Schultz et al. 2012). Moreover, NMs could act as carriers to bring heavy metal ions or organic pollutants into organisms (Fan et al. 2011). Once released into the environment, NMs will undergo transformations due to the impact of various environmental factors (such as light, ionic strength, water hardness, and natural organic matter (NOM)) (Lowry et al. 2012b). These transformations could result in the alteration of toxicity of NMs (Loza et al. 2014; Reinsch et al. 2012). Among them, NOM has attracted a lot of attention, which has highly heterogeneous compositions and abundant functional groups, leading to the inevitable interactions between NMs and NOM (Lawrence et al. 2016; Xu et al. 2018). It has been found that NOM may be adsorbed onto the surface of NMs and form an environmental corona in aquatic environments, which is also known as the ecological corona (or ‘eco-corona’) (Nasser et al. 2020; Pulido-Reyes et al. 2017; Xu et al. 2020). NOM can fully affect the environmental behavior, bioaccumulation and toxicity of NMs compared to other environmental conditions (Li et al. 2018a; Makama et al. 2016; Zhou and Keller 2010). Various studies have recognized that NOM-coated NMs are the most relevant form for assessing the environmental behavior and toxicity risks of NMs rather than the pristine NMs (Markiewicz et al. 2018; Natarajan et al. 2021).

The mechanisms by which NOM influences the toxicity of NMs have been investigated to a certain extent (Wang et al. 2016b). It is clear that an eco-corona will change the surface properties of NMs, whereas the unbound NOM will affect the bioavailability of dissolved ions from NMs through chelation or ligand-promoted dissolution (Aiken et al. 2011) or may compete with NMs with eco-corona (Zhao et al. 2020). Several studies suggested that unbound NOM may interact with organisms to change the toxicity of NMs (Bo et al. 2017; Lin et al. 2012). It has been reported that surface properties (such as functionalization, surface charge, and hydrophobicity) critically influence the cellular uptake, transport and fate of NMs (Zhu et al. 2013), and therefore, it is anticipated that there should be a connection between the composition of an eco-corona and the bioaccumulation or toxicity of NMs (Monikh et al. 2021).

Until now, several reviews have been published to discuss the influence of an eco-corona on the environmental behavior and toxicity of NMs (Markiewicz et al. 2018; Wang et al. 2016b; Xu et al. 2020; Yu et al. 2018). Although some reviews have already discussed the environmental behavior and transformation of NMs in the presence of NOM (Grillo et al. 2015; Lowry et al. 2012a), the current work focuses on the ecological impact and fate assessment of NMs containing an eco-corona with non-coated particles, and therefore, it combines the environmental fate with observed toxicity in a more efficient and comprehensive way. Secondly, some previous reviews have reported that the behavior and toxicity of NMs affected by NOM are complex phenomena (Nasser et al. 2020; Wang et al. 2016b; Xu et al. 2020). However, in our opinion, these reviews still do not systematically answer the question whether an eco-corona promotes or inhibits the toxicity of NMs. The current review is focused more on bioaccumulation and toxicity mechanisms of NMs that contain an eco-corona. The review combines bioaccumulation and toxicity, and allows these dual impacts of an eco-corona to be better explained. Finally, this study has discussed the effects of an eco-corona on the adsorption, transformation and toxicity of other pollutants (such as heavy metals and organic pollutants) in aquatic environments for the first time. Overall, in this study we intend to specifically consider the critical role of the eco-corona in modifying the behavior, fate, and toxicity of NMs. This review assists in clarifying the knowledge gaps regarding the impact of an eco-corona on the biological effects of NMs.

sec.title: NMs in the aquatic environment
sec.p: The release of engineered NMs may be due to their discharge after applications or during the applied process or through direct emission during their manufacturing. NMs enter the environment mainly through (treated) wastewater, sewage sludge, and waste incineration (Buzea et al. 2007; Ding et al. 2022; Gottschalk and Nowack 2011). Based on model simulations, the predicted environmental concentration (PEC) of nanomaterials could reach the range of ng-μg/L in surface waters (Wagner et al. 2014). Peters et al. reported that particle concentrations in Dutch surface waters lied within the ranges of 0.3–2.5 ng/L for Ag, 0.4–5.2 ng/L for CeO2 and 0.2–8.1 μg/L for TiO2 (Peters et al. 2018). The concentrations of NMs fluctuated greatly, especially near ‘point sources’ of engineered NMs (such as outfall from the production plant, waste treatment plants and personal consumer products). Kaegi et al. reported that the released nanosized TiO2 and Ag could reach the concentrations of as high as 600 μg TiO2/L (20–300 nm) and 145 μg Ag/L at the source (Kaegi et al. 2010; Kägi et al. 2008).

As for the natural NMs, it is estimated that billions of tons of natural NMs are formed every year (Hochella et al. 2019), and the environmental concentration of natural NMs is likely to reach the level of mg/L. The chemical composition of natural NMs is always found to be heterogeneous, whereas they are polydisperse by nature. There are two main types of inorganic colloids in the aquatic environment, called the silicates (such as clay, mica, and chlorite) and the oxides and hydrous oxides of iron (such as hematite and magnetite). Besides, natural colloids in freshwater systems always contain both the organic and inorganic components (Ouyang et al. 2018; Stolpe et al. 2010). In the marine system, natural colloids are always composed of organic macromolecules, such as proteins and polysaccharides (Boon et al. 1998; Guo and Santschi 1997).

sec.title: Where does NOM come from?
sec.p: In the aquatic environment, NOM plays an important functional role in biogeochemical processes. Briefly speaking, NOM can be divided into autochthonous (organic compounds released or decomposed by organisms, such as protein, lipid and nucleic acid) and allochthonous fractions (decomposed from terrestrial plant residues, such as humic substances) (Docter et al. 2015; Hudson et al. 2007; Jiang et al. 2017). In freshwater, NOM mainly originates from soil and terrestrial plants, whereas humic substances are the main constituents of NOM, which account for 40–80% of the total NOM content (Kitis et al. 2001). In oceans, NOM mainly originates from the marine organisms, including amino acids, polysaccharides and lipids, which only account for 0.7–2.4% of humic substances (Ogawa and Tanoue 2003). The dissolved organic carbon (DOC) of NOM in surface water typically lies within the range of 1–50 mg/L (Redman et al. 2002), whereas the concentration of NOM in the ocean is around 0.5 mg/L (Ogawa and Tanoue 2003). The chemical complexity of NOM in the aquatic environment is orders-of-magnitude greater than that in any single organism. For instance, Zark et al. estimated that there were at least 100,000 different compounds in NOM (Zark et al. 2017). In general, the types and quantities of NOM in different types of water bodies vary greatly. Despite the variation in the size of NOM, only the fraction of dissolved organic matter of NOM with a size smaller than 0.45 μm, mostly < 20 nm, plays a significant role in the formation of an eco-corona on the surface of NMs. It is important to note that NOM molecule with a size equal or slightly larger than a NM might collide with the particles to form hetero-aggregates, which are out of the scope of this review.

sec.title: Driving forces at the nano-eco interface
sec.p:
While entering the aquatic environment, NMs interact with NOM through the driving forces at the interface of nano-biomolecules (Fig. 1). These forces may involve electrostatic and van der Waals forces, steric interactions, π-π stacking, ligand exchange, cation bridging, chelation, hydrogen (H)-bonding, hydrophobic interaction, and covalent bonding (Philippe and Schaumann 2014; Wang et al. 2016b; Yu et al. 2018). In most of the systems, several driving forces simultaneously contribute to the formation of an eco-corona. Basically, these forces depend on the intrinsic properties of NMs and NOM. However, they can be strongly influenced by the prevailing environmental conditions. For instance, the ionic strength is much higher in seawater than in freshwater. This feature would strongly suppress the electrostatic interaction, while increasing the hydrophobic interaction (Hu et al. 2013). The possible driving forces for different types of NMs are summarized below, whereas it is acknowledged that the main driving force relies on the type of NOM and the ambient conditions in different systems. Apart from that, the surface properties of NMs could be changed by capping agents, resulting in NOM's interacting with the capping agents. Considering this option, only the driving forces originating from pristine NMs are discussed below. Moreover, electrostatic interaction was not discussed as it is highly dependent on the composition of the capping agents and the ambient pH value.Fig. 1
Schematic of the driving forces at the interface of nano-biomolecules (Philippe and Schaumann 2014)

Biomolecules could interact with metallic NMs through charge transfer, ion chelation or chemical bonding due to the high reactivity and surface energy of metals. Charge transfer often occurs between the metals and oxygen or nitrogen-rich groups (Guerrini et al. 2007). It is also employed for detecting small organic molecules using surface-enhanced Raman scattering. Apart from that, nitrogen-rich groups (such as amides, amines, and heterocyclic nitrogen) present in NOM could act as electron donors and exhibit a strong chelation capability for metal ions. For instance, Kumar et al. reported that amine groups mainly interacted with Au ions adsorbed on Au NMs (Kumar et al. 2003). As for the sulfur-containing groups, they always exhibited high affinity for metallic NMs due to the formation of metal-sulfur bonds. The formation of metal-sulfur bond is most frequently observed for Ag and Au NMs. For instance, Zhang et al. investigated the binding affinity between Au NMs and various proteins, and found that Au NMs exhibit a stronger affinity for proteins with a higher content of cysteine (Cys) (Zhang et al. 2017b). Interestingly, a few studies have reported that Ag NMs preferentially adsorb sulfur and nitrogen-rich organic matters (Baalousha et al. 2018; Gunsolus et al. 2015). This finding is consistent with the above discussion.

The interactions between NOM and metal-oxide NMs also include the interaction mechanisms for NOM and metal NMs, such as chelation and charge transfer. However, for ionic oxides such as MgO, the degree of charge transfer is very small, while for SiO2 and TiO2, a pronounced charge transfer at the interface is observed. For instance, Munir et al. reported that carminic acid mainly interacted with TiO2 through charge transfer (Munir et al. 2015). In addition, the presence of a hydroxyl group on the metal-oxide NMs also brought some specific driving forces. For metal-oxide and non-metal-oxide NMs, hydroxyl groups on the nano-surface may form hydrogen bonds with polar groups. For instance, the NH2 and OH groups present in proteins were reported to form N-H···O and O–H···O hydrogen bonds with surface hydroxyl groups in TiO2 (Xu et al. 2010a) and SiO2 NMs (Xu et al. 2010b). In addition, as there are abundant carboxyl/hydroxyl functional groups in NOM, ligand exchange always plays a critical role. Yang et al. compared the adsorption behavior of HA on four types of nano-oxides (TiO2, SiO2, Al2O3 and ZnO), and found that the electrostatic attraction and ligand exchange interactions between HA and nano-oxides (Yang et al. 2009).

Some of the metal sulfide NMs may originate from engineered products with potential application in environmental remediation (Gong et al. 2016). More importantly, natural or secondary formed metal sulfide NMs have been widely found in sulfidic environments (Labrenz et al. 2000; Sekine et al. 2015; Weber et al. 2009). Although sulfidation is an important transformation process of metal NMs, most of the existing studies have focused on the influence of NOM on the environmental behavior or toxicity mechanism of sulfide NMs, while the interaction mechanisms between NOM and metal sulfide NMs are still unclear. As for ZnS, Gondikas et al. reported that Cys (and not the serine) could increase the colloidal stability by getting adsorbed onto the particle surfaces (Gondikas et al. 2010). Similarly, Lau et al. reported that HA and thiol-containing ligands (Cys, glutathione, and thioglycolate) could significantly stabilize ZnS particles (Lau and Hsu-Kim 2008). In contrast, Deonarine et al. reported that the molecular weight and aromatic content of NOM fractions significantly influenced the stability of ZnS NMs, while the carboxylate and reduced sulfur content had little effect on the stability of ZnS NMs (Deonarine et al. 2011).

As for the polymeric and carbon-based NMs, the interactions of nano-biomolecules always involve π-π stacking, hydrophobic interactions and H-bonding. Basically, π-π stacking originates from the weak interactions among aromatic rings, whereas hydrophobic interactions usually occur among nonpolar molecules. For instance, Chen et al. reported that polystyrene micro/nano plastics interacted with the aromatic structure of HA through π-π conjugation, whereas plastics were entrapped in the HA polymers through carboxyl groups and C=O bonds (Chen et al. 2018). Such interactions highly depended on the size of polystyrene micro/nano plastics, and a significant interaction was only observed between the nano-sized polystyrene and HA (Chen et al. 2018). However, current data regarding the adsorption mechanism of NOM on polymeric NMs are still scarce, and largely focused on humic substances and polystyrene. Future work involving different NOM types should be considered. Different kinds of NOM may largely reshape the surface properties of polymer NMs, which would further influence the transport of NMs, especially the widely existing microplastics.

Compared with polymeric NMs, investigations have focused on the interactions between NOM and carbon NMs, such as graphene, single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), and fullerene. These carbon NMs are quite abundant due to their superior adsorption capabilities for organic contaminants. For instance, Zhao et al. compared the influence of 16 kinds of organic matters on the stability of MWCNTs (Zhao et al. 2016), and found that organic matters with higher aromaticity and polarity could increase the stability of MWCNTs more effectively, indicating that the π-π stacking and the formation of H-bonding served as the main driving forces.

Finally, interactions among heterologous organic matters also play an important role. Considering that the concentration of NMs in the aquatic environment is always several orders of magnitudes lower than the NOM concentration, the interactions among NOM may be more dominant for the formation of eco-corona. The strong interactions among NOM may lead to the attachment of NOM with a low affinity for NMs to nano-surfaces by combining with NOM of high affinity. In addition, such interactions may also prevent the adsorption of NOM with high affinity. For instance, Shakiba et al. reported that a mixture of bovine serum albumin (BSA) and NOM inhibited the adsorption of BSA on nano-TiO2 due to the interaction between BSA and NOM (Shakiba et al. 2018). Similarly, Wang et al. found that the steric hindrance of BSA increased due to the combination with HA, which further reduced the adsorption of BSA on Ag NMs (Wang et al. 2018).

sec.title: Influence mechanism of the eco-corona on the environmental behavior of NMs
sec.p: The formation of an eco-corona could influence the dispersion/aggregation status of NMs through modification of the surface charge, the increase in the steric repulsion and induction of the bridging interaction (Peng et al. 2017; Wang et al. 2021). For instance, Miao et al. reported that alginate hindered the aggregation of nano-CuO through increased steric hindrance and electrostatic repulsion (Miao et al. 2016). However, under a high Ca2+ concentration (> 6 mM), Ca2+ induced the bridging of HA to promote the aggregation of NMs. Zhu et al. found that HA could accelerate the aggregation of nano-TiO2 through charge neutralization and bridging (Zhu et al. 2014). The relative roles of these two mechanisms mainly depended on the ionic strength of the solution. Several studies have evaluated the potential effect of NOM on the stability of NMs through theoretical simulations. Zhu et al. compared the stability of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP)-coated nano-Ag, HA-coated nano-Ag, nano-Ag2S and HA-coated nano-Ag2S with classic DLVO theory, and found no distinct difference among these NMs (Zhu et al. 2016). However, the developed XDLVO theory exhibited that HA-coated Ag NMs were more stable than other NMs, due to the reason that steric hindrance, rather than the electrostatic repulsion, dominated the stability of NMs with macromolecular coating. Han et al. also reported that steric hindrance played a critical role in the dispersion of carbon black NMs. Besides, the adsorption of HA also increased the electrostatic repulsion to increase the stability of NMs (Han et al. 2017).

The influence of an eco-corona on the dispersion/aggregation status of NMs would further change the reactive surface area of NMs in the aquatic environment, which changes the dissolution behavior of NMs (Hedberg et al. 2019; Jiang et al. 2022). For instance, researchers found that Suwannee River’s humic acid (SRHA) increased the suspension of nano-Ag and nano-CuO in freshwater, which increased the dissolution of these NMs (Ellis et al. 2016; Wang et al. 2011). On the other hand, NOM could also act as a chelating agent to bind with the released metal ions, which might increase the dissolution of NMs. For instance, many studies have pointed out that amino acid could accelerate the dissolution of Cu-based NMs due to high binding affinity between amino acids and Cu ions (Gunawan et al. 2011; Naatz et al. 2020; Wang and Wang 2021; Wang et al. 2019b; Wang et al. 2013). Similarly, Miao et al. found that cysteine increased the dissolution of ZnO NMs (Miao et al. 2010). Gondicas et al. reported that cysteine elevated the dissolution of Ag NMs (Gondikas et al. 2012).

As for the metal-based NMs that are easily dissolved in aquatic environment, NOM could change the chemical properties and morphology of NMs. In particular, the reducing capability of humic substance could lead to the secondary nucleation of NMs. Hou et al. reported that, with the increase in illumination time, HA changed the morphology of nano-Ag from spherical to triangular, then to hexagonal and eventually to rod-like structure (Hou et al. 2013). Yu et al. found that Ag NMs formed smaller nano-Ag in the presence of HA and light (Yu et al. 2014). Besides, for these NOM containing sulfur, they may lead to the sulfidation of NMs. Miclaus et al. found that amino acid and proteins could result in the sulfidation of nano-Ag (Miclaus et al. 2016).

sec.title: Dual role of an eco-corona in the accumulation/toxicity behavior of NMs
sec.p: For most of the studies, the methods of determining the influence of an eco-corona on the biological effects of NMs consisted of exposing organisms to a mixture of organic matter and NMs, and comparing the biological effects (such as bioaccumulation, mortality rate, and biochemical indicators) with those under the exposure of NMs alone. Only a few studies have removed free organic matter through centrifugation to determine the influence of an eco-corona on the biological effects of NMs (Lin et al. 2012). The formation of an eco-corona was proven by the change of zeta potential in most studies, whereas the decrease in the concentration of organic matter in the solution as well as shifts in the infrared spectrum and SEM were also used to confirm the formation of an eco-corona (Liang et al. 2020a; Zhao et al. 2019). As for the proteins, several studies used sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis technology (SDS-PAGE) to separate and detect the coated proteins (Fadare et al. 2020).

Numerous studies have investigated the influence of an eco-corona on the toxicity or bioaccumulation of NMs to aquatic organisms involving different trophic levels. As shown in Fig. 2, the intrinsic properties of NOM could lead to contradictory effects on the toxicity or bioaccumulation of NMs. Although most of the potential mechanisms have been uncovered and discussed (Arvidsson et al. 2020), it was still largely infeasible to predict the influence of an eco-corona. The chaos originated from the complexity of influencing factors including NMs, organic matter, testing organisms and ambient environment. From the perspective of research objects (NMs, organic matter and test organisms) involved in the modification of biological effects of NMs using an eco-corona (as shown in Fig. 3), nano-eco-bio interactions were reviewed using 235 experiments taken from 119 publications (listed in Table S1). The database was screened according to the most frequently studied ten types of NMs. It is worth noticing that humic substances such as HA and fulvic acid (FA) accounted for most of the investigations on nano-eco-bio interactions. However, the heterogeneity of humic substances could be an important factor, which induces contradictory data for similar NMs, with organic matter being reported to either promote or hinder the internalization of NMs (Li et al. 2018b; Zhang et al. 2019a; Zhong et al. 2020). For example, NOM with high molecular weight could decrease the internalization of NMs more significantly than the NOM with low molecular weight (Liang et al. 2020b; Zhao et al. 2020). Li et al. found that the sulfhydryl group in NOM could significantly reduce the bioavailability of Ag NMs, as compared to the hydroxyl group or the carboxylic group (Li et al. 2018a). On the contrary, studies focusing on simple molecules are relatively inadequate. Therefore, which molecules of NOM are most likely to influence the biological fate of NMs is still unclear. A few studies implied that protein-like NOM may play a critical role (Lu et al. 2017), however direct evidence supporting this hypothesis is lacking. Even for the same organic matter, both inhibitory and promotional effects were reported for the bioaccumulation of NMs (Wang et al. 2019c; Wilhelm et al. 2003), suggesting that the type of organism also matters. As for bacteria and algae, the presence of cell walls is often thought to hinder the internalization of NMs (Wang et al. 2019a). For single-cell aquatic organisms, the direct interactions between NMs and membranes involve passive diffusion, endocytosis and phagocytosis. For other aquatic organisms, different structures of biological tissues, feeding and metabolic modes can change the influence of an eco-corona. In this respect, it is worth noticing that studies on aquatic organisms at different trophic levels are disproportionate, as can be seen from Fig. 3. Figure 3 shows that studies focusing on aquatic plants, benthonic organisms and unicellular animals are scarce.Fig. 2
Influence of an eco-corona on the toxicity or bioaccumulation of nanomaterials (NMs) to aquatic organismsFig. 3
Schematic of the experiments on nano-eco-bio interactions focusing on the influence of NOM on the toxicity or bioaccumulation of NMs to aquatic organisms. Data from Table S1 (the thickness of the lines represents the relative number of experimental studies, while the thicker the lines, the richer the relevant studies)

Considering the triple factors that are important in the nano-eco-bio interactions, it is still not certain to predict the potential effect of NMs with a known eco-corona composition. We have screened database from the past 31 years (1990–2021), which describes the effect of NOM on the toxicity/accumulation of NMs. As shown in Fig. 4, for the four most studied types of NOM (HA, NOM, FA, and BSA), a given eco-corona could act as a shield or an accomplice in the accumulation/toxicity process of NMs. Other types of NOM can also cause such a phenomenon. Several factors may be responsible for the dual role of NOM coating, as discussed in the following.Fig. 4
Statistical chart of the accumulation/toxicity tests of different types of NOM on NMs

a) This could be due to the diverse and complex molecular composition of NOM, especially with regards to humic substances (such as HA, FA, and NOM). As an artificially defined mixture, the composition of humic substances is highly related to the history and ambient environment of their origin, which results in the possibility of a similarly named NOM exhibiting distinct properties. In addition, the composition of an eco-corona would also differ with the surface properties of NMs for a given NOM. For instance, Baalousha et al. found that NOM with high molecular weight was easily adsorbed onto Pt NMs, whereas the composition of corona depended on the molecular characteristics of NOM and the surface properties of Pt NMs (Baalousha et al. 2022). Giannopoulos et al. studied the adsorption of Suwannee River fulvic acid (SRFA) onto Au NMs with different surface coatings, and reported that positively charged branched polyethylenimine (PEI) -coated Au NMs efficiently adsorbed larger oxygen-rich aromatics, while negatively charged citric acid and tannic acid adsorbed oxygen-containing aromatics (Giannopoulos et al. 2021). As discussed earlier, the preferential adsorption of NOM molecules on different types of NMs has been well-studied. Unfortunately, data regarding the influence of the composition of an eco-corona on the biological effects of NMs are still scarce due to the complexity of identifying the composition of NOM. The completion of such works would be quite meaningful for predicting the potential risks of NMs.

b) A simple molecule could also play a dual role, depending on the types of NMs or the organisms. Taking BSA as an example, Fan’s group (Liang et al. 2020a; Wang et al. 2019c) concluded that the effect of BSA coating on the accumulation of NMs in Tetrahymena thermophila depended on the type of NMs, or more specifically, on the uptake pathway of NMs. Using a two-step model, they proposed a general mechanism for explaining the impact of NOM coating on the bioaccumulation of NMs. This mechanism implies that NOM coating always reduces the interactions between cell membranes and NMs. However, some NOM (such as protein) is capable of compensating for such a loss in the interaction by increasing the internalization capability of NMs. Nevertheless, it is still uncertain whether this is a general rule for other aquatic species or not.

c) Environmental conditions (such as ionic strength, hardness, dissolved oxygen, pH, and nutrient elements) may influence the effect of an eco-corona. As shown in Fig. 4, only a few reports describe that NOM increased the toxicity/bioaccumulation of NMs, implying that such effects required stringent environmental conditions. Although few studies have directly investigated the potential effects of environmental conditions, there are still some clues implying that their impacts have been overlooked. For instance, Wang et al. reported that the types and patterns of NOM adsorbed onto NMs in aquatic environments with different ionic strengths (freshwater and seawater) were different, resulting in different toxicities of Ag NMs to Escherichia coli (Wang et al. 2018). On the other hand, Mineau et al. reported that individual additions of N and P could increase the consumption of DOC by 42% and 23%, respectively (Mineau et al. 2013). The role of environmental conditions in nano-eco-bio interactions is therefore to be studied further in future works.

sec.title: Mechanisms by which NOM influences the uptake of NMs by aquatic organisms
sec.p: For most NMs, their bioaccumulation is the main reason for their nanotoxicity, as NMs that are not transferred across the cell membrane may result in limited toxicological effects. Meanwhile, the accumulation of NMs in organisms could result in trophic transfer to their predators, eventually posing a potential risk to human beings. Firstly, as for the eco-corona, it would affect the aggregation and suspension of NMs. In most cases, the eco-corona could promote the dispersion of NMs, reduce the size of agglomerates, and further promote their suspension. Some cations (such as Ca2+ and Mg2+) may induce aggregation and sedimentation of NMs containing eco-corona through cation bridging. As NOM usually has a negative charge, a low concentration of NOM would also induce the aggregation of positively charged NMs due to charge neutralization, whereas a further increase in the content of NOM would promote the dispersion of NMs (Chekli et al. 2013). The change in the stabilization of suspension may affect the bioaccumulation of NMs by changing the feeding behavior of organisms or the internalization pathway of NMs. As for the unicellular organisms, large-sized agglomerated particles would limit their entrance into the cells. Wang et al. found that the better suspension of CuO NMs in the presence of FA was one of the main reasons for higher accumulation of CuO NMs in prokaryotic algae Microcystis aeruginosa (Wang et al. 2011). In case of filter feeders, NOM could effectively filter particles with sizes within a certain range, such as Daphnia magna, which typically ingests particles within the size range of 0.5–40 μm (Demott 1982). Sikder et al. reported that, with the increased size of Pt NMs, the uptake rate of Pt NMs increased, whereas the elimination rate decreased by amphipods (Sikder et al. 2021). Lu et al. found that graphene with a larger size exhibited higher bioaccumulation. However, graphene was mainly located in the gill and intestine of zebrafish (Lu et al. 2017). On the other hand, smaller graphene sheets exhibited lower bioaccumulation and could be transferred into brain, liver and roe. In addition, large-sized agglomerated particles would further facilitate the sedimentation of NMs, which influences the transport of NMs in the aquatic environment. Therefore, a high suspension performance of NMs may increase their risks for fish or zooplankton (Adeleye et al. 2014), while the sedimentation of NMs may increase their likelihood of exposure to sediment dwelling organisms (Poynton et al. 2013).

Once in contact with the cell membrane, the eco-corona could affect the membrane-adsorption capability, intake pathway, or bioavailability of NMs. By building an artificial phospholipid bilayer and the use of quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) technology, it has been acknowledged that the membrane-adsorption capability of NMs was related to their surface charge, coating, particle size and shape, whereas the environmental conditions also mattered (Chen et al. 2016). While using bacteria and algae as the model organisms, many reports have found that an eco-corona was capable of shielding cells from NMs through electrostatic repulsion and steric hindrance (Han et al. 2019; Schultz et al. 2021; Wang et al. 2016b; Zhang et al. 2019a; Zhao et al. 2013). Especially, Liu et al. reported that the damage to cell membrane, induced by Ag2S NMs, was negatively correlated with the thickness and softness of the coating layer. It quantitatively confirmed the influence of the eco-corona on the repulsive force (Liu et al. 2018c). Even though only a limited number of studies have shown that an eco-corona could also increase the adsorption of NMs on cell membranes/walls, the underlying mechanisms are still unknown (Arenas-Lago et al. 2019). Interestingly, Melby et al. reported a unique case of protein coating increasing the deposition of ultra-small NMs on the artificial phospholipid bilayer (Melby et al. 2017). Therefore, it is clear that specific driving forces may exist between an eco-corona and membranes under some specific environmental conditions.

NMs can be internalized through phagocytosis, macro pinocytosis, clathrin mediated endocytosis, caveolin mediated endocytosis, clathrin/caveolin independent endocytosis, and direct penetration (Liu et al. 2022a; Liu et al. 2022b; Zhu et al. 2013). The intake pathway of NMs depends on their size, surface coating and shape. Therefore, it is reasonable to expect that a specific eco-corona will affect their intake pathways. Unfortunately, related research using environmentally relevant NOM is scarce in the literature. Wang et al. reported that the coating of BSA or HA would not affect the intake pathway of Ag NMs with alkyl groups (Wang et al. 2019c). Similarly, Sharma et al. found that the intake pathways for polystyrene particles of different sizes were independent of surface-modification (BSA or PEG coating) (Sharma et al. 2019), suggesting that small organic matter molecules would more effectively influence the intake pathway of NMs.

Finally, an eco-corona could influence the bioavailability of NMs, which represents the internalization capacity of NMs being transported into the cells. The assessment of bioaccumulation of NMs is usually used to compare their bioavailability. However, it should be noticed that bioaccumulation is the combined result of membrane-adsorption and internalization. Wilhelm et al. proposed a kinetic model to describe both the membrane adsorption and subsequent internalization or endocytosis, which followed the currently accepted mechanism for cellular uptake of NMs (Lesniak et al. 2013; Wilhelm et al. 2002). In this model, NMs adsorbed onto cellular membranes according to the Langmuir adsorption model, and then due to the reactive surface of the membrane, passed through the membranes. The limited reactive membrane surface, which is related to the receptor or coating of NMs, determines whether the adsorbed NMs would be transferred indefinitely or not. The two-step bioaccumulation process indicates that the eco-corona could simultaneously play contradictory roles in the uptake of NMs. For instance, with an increase in the concentration of NOM, the eco-corona could increase the internalization capacity of NMs, while decreasing the membrane adsorption of NMs. This explains why the relationship between the bioaccumulation of NMs and the concentration of NOM could present an inverse-V shape variation trend (Arenas-Lago et al. 2019; Wang et al. 2019c). Liang et al. calculated that protein coating significantly increased the internalization capacity of NMs, while HA coating could not achieve the same results (Liang et al. 2020b). It is supposed that NOM with high bioavailability would be more likely to increase the internalization capacity of NMs. The conformation or orientation of NOM may also matter, as it was found that the change in the conformation of protein would weaken the bioavailability of NMs (Liang et al. 2020a). Similarly, as for the organisms, the initial organs (such as intestine of D. magna, or intestine and gill of fish) would play the same role as the cell membranes in accumulating NMs. The transfer capability of NMs into other organs or blood would determine the total accumulation and biodistribution of NMs.

sec.title: Mechanisms by which NOM influences the toxicity of NMs by aquatic organisms
sec.p: To date, the toxicity mechanisms of NMs to aquatic organisms at different trophic levels have been well-investigated. At the cellular level, the generally accepted toxicity mechanisms include membrane damage, oxidative stress, organelle damage, enzyme inactivation, DNA damage, and toxic ion release (Demir 2021; Lim et al. 2021; Nel et al. 2006). At the organismal level, NMs could inhibit the growth and reproduction of organisms at sublethal concentrations (Fan et al. 2016b), or induce pathological changes in targeted organs (Shaw and Handy 2011). On the whole, the toxicity of most NMs originates from their negative effects on the normal metabolism of cells or organisms, which are therefore related to the bioaccumulation of NMs. For instance, the metal-containing NMs are known to induce toxicity through the release of toxic ions in the lysosome after endocytosis (Sabella et al. 2014). In other cases, metal NMs could release ions at specific microenvironments (such as gut) in the organisms (Wang et al. 2015; Yan et al. 2018). The influence of the eco-corona on the toxicity of NMs might originate from their influence on the release of metal (Monikh et al. 2020) and from their effects on the bioaccumulation of NMs. Liang et al. found that Ag NMs and nano zero valent iron (nZVI) with an eco-corona exhibited similar toxicity as pristine NMs in vivo, as the effects of NOM on the toxicity of NMs mainly resulted from the changes in the bioaccumulation of NMs (Liang et al. 2020a). However, Yang et al. (Yang et al. 2013) reported that the addition of HA decreased the concentration of Ti associated with fish, and increased the toxicity of TiO2 NMs. These results were similar to the findings of Liang et al. (Liang et al. 2020a). The differences among toxicity mechanisms of NMs may be responsible for this finding; however, more specific work is required to understand the difference between the effects of NMs with an eco-corona and those without an eco-corona.

a) Membrane damage. Carbon-based NMs, such as MWCNTs and graphene-family materials, are known to induce membrane damage through mechanical interactions (Hu et al. 2014; Schlagenhauf et al. 2015; Zhang et al. 2019b; Zhao et al. 2014). As for the graphene oxide, Zucker et al. reported that the extent of membrane damage depended on the total surface area of graphene oxide (Zucker et al. 2017). Normally, an eco-corona could hinder the physical contact between graphene and cell membranes through steric hindrance or electrostatic repulsion, which could reduce membrane damage (Zhang et al. 2016; Zhao et al. 2019). For invertebrate animals or zebrafish larvae, a few studies reported that HA could significantly increase the toxicity of graphene to organisms by enhancing its stability (Castro et al. 2018; Clemente et al. 2017). This was mainly because of the enhanced stability, which increased the accumulation of graphene in the gills or intestines, thereby influencing the normal metabolism in organisms. Polystyrene NMs could directly penetrate the cell membrane and the hydrophobicity of the particles could destroy the structure of cell membranes (Liang et al. 2020a; Liu et al. 2018b). An eco-corona would increase the hydrophilicity of polystyrene NMs, which in turn reduced the membrane damage.

b) Generation of the reactive oxygen species (ROS). Due to their unique electronic structure, metal-oxide NMs can exhibit excellent antibacterial properties through photogenerated ROS (Li et al. 2016b; Li et al. 2012c). The general principle is that a photon with an energy greater than the band gap excites the electrons of NMs across the band gap to the conduction band, creating a hole in the valence band. The electron in the conduction band can react with molecular oxygen to produce the superoxide anion through a reductive process, while the hole in the valence band can attract electrons from water or from hydroxyl ions to generate hydroxyl radicals through an oxidative process (Li et al. 2016b). Li et al. compared the antibacterial properties of engineered metal-oxide NMs (TiO2, ZnO, Al2O3, SiO2, Fe2O3 and CeO2 NMs) under UV irradiation and found that the production capability of ROS by NMs was quantitatively related to their antibacterial activity (Li et al. 2012c). Among various NMs, TiO2 exhibited the most robust antibacterial properties because of the highest production capability of ROS. However, the wavelength of the excited light could be used to critically determine the generation efficiency of ROS by NMs. For instance, blocking the UV light would drastically reduce the antibacterial activity of TiO2 NMs (Tong et al. 2013).

Various studies have reported that Suwannee River’s natural organic matter (SRNOM) reduces the toxicity of TiO2 to certain organisms, mainly by quenching the ROS generated by the TiO2 NMs (Farner et al. 2019; Li et al. 2016a; Wormington et al. 2017). Li et al. reported that both HA and FA increased the phototoxicity of CeO2 and SiO2 and reduced the phototoxicity of ZnO and CuO (Li et al. 2016b). However, the NMs had no effect on the phototoxicity of TiO2. Such differences might be related to different ROS species induced by the NMs and to the electron transfer between the NMs and the NOM. Under UV irradiation, TiO2 and ZnO NMs could generate three types of ROSs (superoxide radicals, hydroxyl radicals, and singlet oxygen), whereas Fe2O3 NMs could generate superoxide and hydroxyl radicals. Moreover, Al2O3 and SiO2 NMs could generate singlet oxygen, while CeO2 could generate superoxide radicals. Notably, CuO NMs did not produce any type of ROSs (Li et al. 2012c). When NOM is in its excited state, it can transfer an electron to NMs, after which, the long-lived electron on the surface of NMs can reduce O2, thus producing more superoxide radicals and singlet oxygen (Brunet et al. 2009; Li et al. 2016b). Besides, the quenching efficiency of different NOMs to ROS species is also important. As for NOM, singlet oxygen reacts primarily with the smaller and more hydrophobic fractions of NOM, while hydroxyl radicals are reactive with a much higher fraction of NOM (Brame et al. 2014).

Except for the ROS generated from NMs, NOM itself could produce ROS under light irradiation. For instance, Liu et al. reported that SRHA and SRNOM could generate oxidative radicals (hydrogen peroxide, hydroxyl radical, and singlet oxygen) and reductive radicals (superoxide radical) under simulated sunlight due to the different chemical structures. (Liu et al. 2018a). However, their difference in the generation of ROS resulted in SRNOM being able to reduce Ag+ to Ag NMs more effectively. Apart from the difference of ROS’s generation caused by the composition of NOM, ROS produced by NOM exhibited spatial variability. Latch et al. used a hydrophobic chemiluminescent probe to determine singlet oxygen, and found that the concentration of singlet oxygen at the NOM core was orders of magnitude higher than the singlet oxygen concentration in the solution (Latch and McNeill 2006). This finding suggests that the reactivity of ROS induced by an eco-corona at the nano-surface was more vigorous and dynamic than the ROS reactivity measured in the solution.

Liu et al. found that in an air-saturated solution (pH of 5.68), Ag NMs at different concentrations would be fully dissolved in 6–125 days (Liu and Hurt 2010). Li et al. reported that, compared with a deaeration solution, CdSe/ZnS Quantum dots would release more Cd and Se ions in the air-saturated solution (Li et al. 2012b). As for small organic molecules such as Cys, Liu et al. found that a low Cys/Ag molar ratio inhibited the dissolution of Ag NMs, while a high Cys/Ag molar ratio accelerated the dissolution of NMs (Liu et al. 2010). Further studies suggested that thiol-containing compounds could only accelerate the dissolution of Ag NMs under aerobic conditions (Marchioni et al. 2018).

Accelerating and inhibiting effects of an eco-corona on the dissolution of NMs have both been reported. In fact, an eco-corona can accelerate the dissolution of NMs in two ways: 1) by facilitating the dispersion of NMs, which return increases the surface area of the NMs available for dissolution (Ellis et al. 2016; Wang et al. 2011); and 2) by combining with metal ions. This process accelerates the release of ions (Miao et al. 2010) as a corona is always dynamic and capable of constantly exchanging substances with the ambient environment (Miclaus et al. 2016). On the other hand, an eco-corona could shield the reaction between metal and H+ or O2 to inhibit the dissolution of NMs. For instance, Li et al. reported that low concentrations of HA could accelerate the dissolution of QDs, while high HA concentrations (above 50 mg/L) would inhibit the release of ions (Li et al. 2012b). In addition, humic substances could reduce metal ions, such as reducing Ag+ to Ag0. They also inhibited the release of ions and reduced the toxicity of NMs (Akaighe et al. 2012). Moreover, it should be noted that even when an eco-corona accelerates the dissolution of NMs, this does not mean that the toxicity has increased, as NOM may combine with free metal ions to reduce toxicity (Rippner et al. 2018).

sec.title: Influence of an eco-corona on the fate and behavior of other contaminants
sec.p: Some studies have reviewed the effects of an eco-corona on the environmental behavior and transformation of NMs (Hedberg et al. 2019; Jawed et al. 2020; Wang et al. 2016b; Xu et al. 2020). However, until now, no review has discussed the influence of an eco-corona on the environmental systems, especially other pollutants that are widely present in the aquatic environment.

The formation of an eco-corona could significantly reshape the surface of NMs, change the speciation and the distribution of other pollutants (such as metal and organic pollutants) in the aquatic environment, and finally, affect the toxicity to aquatic organisms and human health (Lin et al. 2019; Qiao et al. 2019). For instance, the presence of SRNOM promoted the adsorption of Cu2+ on the polystyrene NMs, which resulted in the increased accumulation of Cu and toxicity of livers and guts in zebrafish (Qiao et al. 2019). An eco-corona can change the distribution of trace pollutants between the NMs and the water phase by providing more or fewer active sites for the adsorption of trace pollutants (Fan et al. 2016a; Qiao et al. 2019). Firstly, the promoted dispersion stability of NMs by an eco-corona is one of the reasons for the increased adsorption of trace pollutants by exposing more accessible adsorption sites (Makama et al. 2016). Charge neutralization and bridging mechanisms may also lead to increased particle agglomeration, which may ultimately reduce the number of active sites. Secondly, disregarding the effect on the dispersion stability, an eco-corona can occupy the active sites or pores on NMs to reduce the adsorption of pollutants through competitive adsorption and/or blockage (Hou et al. 2017; Kim et al. 2018b; Zhang et al. 2017a). Fang et al. reported that NOM decreased the adsorption capacity of phenanthrene on carbon nanotubes by 10% because of the competition for adsorption sites, whereas the adsorption capacity for oxytetracycline was reduced by about 50% (Fang et al. 2017). On the other hand, the eco-corona contained a series of functional groups such as carboxyl and hydroxyl groups, which could be combined with trace pollutants through electrostatic forces, complexation, H-bonding and hydrophobic interactions, thus promoting the adsorption of pollutants on NMs (Chen et al. 2012; Zhang et al. 2018). The impact of an eco-corona on active sites mainly depends on the interaction intensity between the eco-corona/NMs and the trace pollutants, which is related to the properties of NMs, the corona and the adsorbed pollutants. For instance, the formation of an eco-corona on carbon NMs inhibited the adsorption of metal and organic pollutants in most cases due to competitive adsorption and micropore blocking (Chen et al. 2012; Kim et al. 2018b; Wang et al. 2008a). On the contrary, for the cases of NOM-coated metal oxide NMs and plastic NMs, contradictory effects were observed because the eco-corona could form a highly conjugated co-polymer with increased electron density and provide more binding sites (Wang et al. 2016a; Wang et al. 2008b; Yang et al. 2009). Thirdly, an eco-corona can change the surface properties (surface charge, hydrophilic/hydrophobic properties, and oxidation properties) of NMs in the environment (Kim et al. 2018a). For instance, an eco-corona on nano plastics can reduce the adsorption of tetracycline mainly due to the change of charge and hydrophobicity of polystyrene (Zhang et al. 2018). Considering the complex factors affecting the nano-eco-trace pollutant interactions and that these factors tend to co-exist, it is difficult to fully predict the impact of an eco-corona on the distribution of pollutants in the aquatic environment. The approach of basic data collection, machine learning and the analysis of big data seem to be a promising way to predict the effects of an eco-corona on the distribution of pollutants.

As discussed earlier, the eco-corona could change the distribution of trace pollutants on NMs (Fadare et al. 2019). These changes would eventually affect the accumulation, transformation and toxicity of trace pollutants in the organisms (Lin et al. 2019). Some studies have described that the increased/decreased adsorption of pollutants on NMs, as affected by an eco-corona, would ultimately increase/decrease the bioavailability of pollutants due to changed bioaccumulation of pollutants (Shen et al. 2014). In contrast, in the presence of NOM, the increased adsorption of Cu2+ on TiO2 NMs reduced their toxicity to Daphnia magna, which was because of a decrease in the bioavailable soluble Cu2+ (Fan et al. 2016a). Unfortunately, there are only a few studies on the effect of an eco-corona on the bioavailability of other pollutants, probably due to the complexity of the system. This lack of knowledge may lead to inaccurate estimates of the ecological risks of various pollutants.

The effect of an eco-corona on the transformation of trace pollutants has also been confirmed. An eco-corona can affect the oxidative and reductive activities of NMs, thereby promoting the degradation of pollutants present on the NMs by directly participating in the electron transfer process (Fan et al. 2016a; Tratnyek et al. 2011). For example, Tratnyek et al. found that several quinone model compounds increased the removal of carbon tetrachloride by nZVI (Tratnyek et al. 2011). NOM adsorbed on nZVI enhanced the migration of electrons and conversion of dissolved oxygen to hydrogen peroxide and hydroxyl radicals, which then promoted the removal of 4-chlorophenol (Kang and Choi 2009). Meanwhile, eco-corona may also hinder the electron transfer process by blocking the active sites of nZVI to reduce the degradation of trichloroethylene and decabromodiphenyl ether (Chen et al. 2011; Tan et al. 2014). Moreover, NOM acted as hole-scavengers and promoted the photocatalytic reduction of pollutants (Tan et al. 2014). According to Zhang et al., the formation of an eco-corona on the iron interface affected the removal of pollutants by inhibiting the metal corrosion (Zhang et al. 2009; Zhang et al. 2010). However, the effects of contaminant transformation as influenced by an eco-corona on ecological risks have not yet been studied.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
This review comprehensively investigated the formation of an eco-corona in the aquatic environment and systematically evaluated the effect of an eco-corona on the uptake and toxic effects of NMs and other pollutants. In general, there are still many challenges in explaining the formation and composition of an eco-corona. This is due to the interactions of complex environmental factors (such as pH, sunlight, and salinity), the complex composition of NOM, and a lack of insight in the toxicological mechanisms of NMs. More efforts should be made to systematically address these challenges. The key issues to be investigated may be divided into four aspects as described below.
The greatest challenge in the research of an eco-corona is still the difficulty of fully and accurately assessing the composition of an eco-corona. One possible solution is to reverse the screen for organic matter that is more readily internalized by organisms, thus focusing on the proportion of these categories of organic matter in the eco-corona.
The dual impact of an eco-corona on NMs and other pollutants may be derived not only from the complexity of the composition of an eco-corona, but also from the diversity of mechanisms influencing the composition of an eco-corona. An eco-corona often changes the surface potential and coating thickness of the particles, which affect the interaction between NMs and organisms. However, some specific organic matter or functional groups in the eco-corona may increase the binding affinity between particles and ligands, thus promoting the internalization of NMs. Combining the more comprehensive data obtained through high-throughput screening techniques as described in issue (1), it is quite desirable to further establish the relationship between the composition of the eco-corona and the accumulation/toxicity of NMs through mathematical modelling (Ban et al. 2020).
Some novel techniques can be used to study the biological effects of an eco-corona such as biological imaging techniques. Specifically, investigating the influence of an eco-corona on the biological effects of NMs in vivo would be one of the most attractive topics. Meanwhile, conducting such a study would also be one of the most difficult tasks. To fully understand the biological impacts of an eco-corona, the transfer or transformation of NMs and eco-corona’s in vivo should be identified. Through multiple labeling of NMs and corona molecules, the intracellular fate of NMs and the corona could be simultaneously tracked (Carrillo-Carrion et al. 2019). Such principles and methodologies could be adapted for studies of the eco-corona. However, the specific challenges for the eco-corona are more complicated, as at present no feasible protocol is established for labeling heterogeneous NOM.
Most studies dealing with eco-coronas are carried out under laboratory conditions. These relatively simple laboratory conditions are far from the real ecological environment (Wang et al. 2016b). This implies that the results obtained under laboratory conditions are difficult to extrapolate to the ‘real’ environment. However, there has been no research studying the effect of an eco-corona in mesocosms. Combining mesocosm studies, high-throughput screening techniques and mathematical modeling, the influences of eco-coronas can be assessed on a large scale.

ack.p: F.A.M. acknowledges the UEF Water research programme, which is jointly funded by Saastamoinen foundation, Wihuri foundation, and Olvi foundation.

sec.title: Authors’ contributions
sec.p: XW and DL: Creating the idea, visualization, investigation, collecting review of literature, creating tables and figures, and writing the original draft. YW: Visualization, writing, review and editing. WP: Writing-review and editing. FAM: Writing-review and editing. XZ: Writing-review and editing. ZD: Writing-review and editing. WF: Creating the idea, visualization, writing-review and editing, and corresponding. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No.41977352, 42177240 and 41925031).

sec.title: Availability of data and materials
sec.p: Not applicable.

sec.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
sec.p: This work is original and is not under consideration for publication elsewhere. None of the aspects of this work has been previously published. Informed consent was obtained from all individual authors included in the study.

sec.title: Consent for publication
sec.p: Authors are responsible for correctness of the statements provided in the manuscript. The publication has been approved by all co-authors.

sec.title: Competing interests
sec.p: The authors declare they have no actual or potential competing financial interests.
